fields.description: Hit a deadlock in the ResourceManager as one thread was holding the SchedulerApplicationAttempt lock and trying to call RMAppAttemptImpl.getMasterContainer while another thread had the RMAppAttemptImpl lock and was trying to call SchedulerApplicationAttempt.getResourceUsageReport.
fields.summary: ResourceManager deadlock between RMAppAttemptImpl and SchedulerApplicationAttempt

comments.body:

{noformat}

Looks like this was caused by YARN-3116 when it added the call to RMAppAttemptImpl.getMasterContainer from SchedulerApplicationAttempt.  That violated the locking order which typically is RMAppAttemptImpl->SchedulerApplicationAttempt.

Could this be the same issue as pointed out by YARN-4247? We did see this issue in our environment (which is 2.6 + patches), but that was because we backported YARN-2005 without YARN-3361. Not sure if there has been a more recent regression.
This appears to have been fixed as a side-effect of YARN-3361 which wasn't in the build that reproduced this issue.  That change updated getMasterContainer to avoid locking the RMAppAttemptImpl.

bq. Could this be the same issue as pointed out by YARN-4247?

It is essentially the same core issue, but it wasn't caused by YARN-2005.  We don't have that change in our build, but we do have YARN-3116.  That's the first time getMasterContainer was called from SchedulerApplicationAttempt.  Without the side-effect of YARN-3361 it leads to a deadlock since getMasterContainer tries to grab the lock.

I feel that a call to {{RMAppAttemptImpl.getMasterContainer }} is not very clean or good from Scheduler side. I mentioned this point once in YARN-2005. Its better we set that AM container is allocated via an Event to Scheduler or via a direct api. But it comes with few lines of extra code. There were few discussions on YARN-4143 for this. Will this be clean solution for this, so that we can remove the dependency.
Resolving since the fix was incorporated into 2.8 as part of YARN-3361.
